The European refugee crisis, as the wave of migration to Europe in 2015 and 2016 was called, began in the spring of 2015 and was caused by the escalation of the war in Syria.

A dispute arose in the European Union over the redistribution of refugees heading to Europe who had already arrived in Greece and Italy. Many countries had reservations about mandatory quotas. However, the loudest opposition came from the Visegrad Four . The quotas were approved by EU interior ministers in September 2015. In December of the same year, Slovakia and Hungary filed a lawsuit with the Court of Justice of the EU against the redistribution of asylum seekers based on quotas. In June 2017, for example, the Czech government decided that it would no longer accept any asylum seekers based on quotas, accepting 12 of the 2,600 people allocated.

The European Commission then decided to open infringement proceedings against the Czech Republic, Hungary and Poland. In September 2017, the relocation programme for applicants from Greece and Italy ended , with 29,144 people out of 160,000 being relocated and only five countries fulfilling their quotas. In April 2020, the Court of Justice of the EU ruled that the Czech Republic, Poland and Hungary had failed to fulfil their obligations under European Union law.

On the contrary, in 2015, German Chancellor Angela Merkel, for example, took a welcoming stance towards accepting refugees with her famous media statement "we will manage it ". At that time, Germany was also the country with the highest number of asylum applications. However, Armin Laschet, the CDU candidate for chancellor in the September German elections, has now expressed the opposite. After the capture of Kabul, he stated that Germany " must not give the impression that we can accept every person in need ".

French President Emmanuel Macron spoke about the need to " defend against illegal migration " after the fall of Kabul. His predecessor, François Hollande, chose a different rhetoric in 2015, saying he would " get the crisis under control " and defending his decision to uphold his refugee admission commitments despite the terrorist attacks in Paris.

Six EU member states, including Germany, the Netherlands and Austria, also sent a letter to the European Commission in early August 2021 warning against halting deportations of rejected Afghan asylum seekers, despite the Taliban's advance in their homeland. However, Germany, along with another signatory of the letter, the Netherlands, subsequently announced that they would not deport the unaccepted Afghans for the time being due to the development of the conflict. However, Austria did not change its position and Austrian Chancellor Sebastian Kurz ruled out accepting people fleeing Afghanistan, saying that this would not happen during his term in office. State agencies and private companies that manage critical information infrastructure or important information systems are required by law to conduct a security audit based on a warning from the National Cybersecurity Office. SECTION E:

The national energy mix represents the share of energy sources in a country. It is an overview of the use of energy from individual primary sources such as fossil fuels (coal, natural gas, oil), nuclear sources and renewable sources (solar, wind, hydro, geothermal and others).

The resulting energy mix varies from region to region and country. It depends on the given natural, economic and social conditions. Historical, geopolitical, environmental and other factors also play a role.

The Czech Republic's energy policy is based on the State Energy Concept of the Czech Republic (.pdf). This represents a long-term national strategy that is set " in accordance with the long-term energy strategy of the European Union focused on decarbonization, high security of supply and competitive energy prices " ( .pdf , p. 5).

European Union legislation in the field of energy focuses mainly on issues of the common market and the environment.

Energy is covered by Title XXI of Part Three of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. Article 194(1) of the Treaty sets out (.pdf, p. 134) the objectives of EU policy and its scope in the field of energy: " To ensure the functioning of the energy market; to ensure the security of energy supply in the Union; to promote energy efficiency and energy saving as well as the development of new and renewable energy sources; and to promote the interconnection of energy networks. "

Paragraph 2 of Article 194 declares (.pdf, p. 135) the independence of Member States in the formulation of their own energy policies. The article states that legislation and measures to achieve the objectives of paragraph 1 shall not affect " the right of a Member State to determine the conditions for the exploitation of its energy resources, its choice between different energy sources and the fundamental composition of its energy supply. "

There are therefore standards and regulations that influence the energy policy of individual EU member states, but the composition of the energy mix is the responsibility of the states.

One of the measures concerning the EU internal market and also affecting the energy sector is illegal aid. This is defined in Article 107 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union: " Any aid granted by a Member State or through State resources in any form whatsoever which distorts or threatens to distort competition by favouring certain undertakings or the production of certain goods shall, in so far as it affects trade between Member States, be incompatible with the internal market, save as otherwise provided in the Treaties " ( .pdf , p. 91).

The Treaty states (.pdf, p. 92) that the Commission monitors the compatibility of state aid with the internal market and may, where appropriate, order the state to abolish or adjust unlawful aid (Article 108(2)).

Furthermore, the Treaty states (.pdf, p. 92) that “ the Commission must be informed in sufficient time of any plans to grant or alter aid in order to enable it to submit its observations. If it considers that such a plan is not compatible with the internal market having regard to Article 107, it shall immediately initiate the procedure referred to in paragraph 2. The Member State concerned shall not put the envisaged measures into effect until the Commission has taken a final decision on the procedure ” (Article 108(3)).

Another example of legislative criteria are environmental commitments. In 2015, the European Commission presented the so-called Energy Union, which aims to ensure a secure, sustainable, affordable and competitive energy system in the EU. There are a number of EU strategies and targets in the field of climate and energy (e.g. Energy Strategy 2030 and 2050 ).

One of the EU requirements is to introduce a 32% share of renewable energy sources by 2030. This and other requirements are implemented by the National Energy and Climate Plan of the Czech Republic (.docx). This climate and energy plan (.docx, pp. 26–27) states that “ The Czech Republic plans to achieve a share of renewable energy sources in gross final consumption of 22% by 2030, which is an increase of 9 percentage points compared to the national target of 13% for 2020. The stated share of 22% corresponds to the requirement to express a national contribution to achieving the binding EU target of 32% by 2030 according to Article 3 of the revised version of Directive 2009/28/EC on the promotion of the use of energy from renewable sources ( Directive 2018/2001 ). “

The National Climate and Energy Plan (.docx, p. 1) corresponds to the priorities of the European Commission, which presented them on November 30, 2016 as part of the "Clean Energy for All Europeans" package .

The EU's nuclear policy is based on the Treaty establishing the European Atomic Energy Community. EU countries decide for themselves whether to include nuclear energy in their energy mixes.

A BIS spokesperson defended himself against Miloš Zeman's statement of October 24, 2019, saying: "The fight against corruption is not within the legal competence of the BIS. This issue is addressed by special units of the Czech Police."

The status and scope of the BIS are determined by Act No. 153/1994 Coll. on the Intelligence Services of the Czech Republic. According to Section 5, the BIS provides information on activities whose consequences may threaten the security or significant economic interests of the Czech Republic. According to the official website of the BIS, a significant economic interest is understood to be an interest in the functionality of systems with a broad economic reach and in the optimal management of assets, the loss of which could threaten the basic functions of the state. The explanatory memorandum to the Act on Intelligence Services speaks of the need to " detect through intelligence efforts also efforts directed against the mechanisms of the financial and economic functioning of the state in cases where their consequences may damage the interests of the Czech Republic". These economic interests may be influenced, among other things, by illegal activities, which can include corruption, although it is not explicitly mentioned in the law or on the BIS website.

It cannot be ruled out that a specific case of corruption that would significantly threaten the economic interests of the Czech Republic could fall within the scope of the BIS. However, in general, the fight against economic crime is not within the scope of the BIS. This is investigated by specialized units of the Czech Police, for example, the Corruption and Financial Crime Detection Unit or the Organized Crime Detection Unit of the SKPV.

President Miloš Zeman, at a meeting with foreign ambassadors on October 27, 2019, did indeed begin his speech with almost identical words: "Distinguished ambassadors, dear guests, ladies and gentlemen, friends of the Czech Republic, welcome to a successful country! We consider the opening words to be true in terms of content as well. The unemployment rate in the Czech Republic is indeed the lowest in the European Union. According to Eurostat data from October 2019 , it is 2.2%, while the average unemployment rate in the EU-28 is 6.3%.

If we measure economic growth by GDP, then the Czech Republic is truly in a period of growth. According to Czech Statistical Office data (.xlsx), GDP has been growing by at least 2.5% year-on-year since 2013.

President Miloš Zeman says that the state debt is relatively decreasing and low. It is true that in relative terms of state debt to GDP, the debt is indeed decreasing. As can be seen in Eurostat data , this trend has been evident since 2013, when the debt was at 44.9%. In 2018, the share of state debt to GDP was 32.6%. However, in absolute numbers, state debt is not clearly decreasing, on the contrary, it is rather fluctuating, which can be traced in the data of the Ministry of Finance . According to Eurostat data, the debt of the Czech Republic is one of the lowest in the EU. The average share of state debt to GDP in the EU is 80.4%. Estonia and Bulgaria, for example, have lower relative state debt than the Czech Republic.

The average wage growth is reported by the Czech Statistical Office . In the 3rd quarter of 2019, the average wage reached CZK 33,697 (increased by 6.9% year-on-year).

The growth of old-age pensions can be monitored, for example, on data from the Ministry of Finance . In 2016, the average old-age pension was CZK 11,460, in 2017 it was CZK 11,850, and in 2018 the average old-age pension reached CZK 12,418.

Petr Fiala talks about the ratio of international and domestic influences that contribute to the increase in inflation. No studies that would determine exactly how individual components contribute to the increase in inflation have apparently been conducted (video, 9:02).

Economists such as Jan Švejnar (video, 0:46) and Štěpán Jurajda (video, 8:57) include, for example, the disruption of import chains, i.e. delays or shortages of some raw materials, among the international influences on price increases. Some input raw materials can also become more expensive, the main ones recently being energy , silicon , chips or building materials such as wood (video, 3:08). The costs of shipping and land transport have also increased. Therefore, this type of inflation is called supply-side inflation (video, 3:08), which is caused by an increase in the prices of inputs to production.

As for the domestic influences that contribute to this wave of rising inflation, we can mention, for example, the words of the head of the National Budget Council , Eva Zamrazilová: "The connection between inflation and the legacy of the previous fiscal policy is obvious, and we have repeatedly pointed out this fact. The problem of inflation certainly cannot be brushed off the table by saying that it is purely global imported inflation."

Economist Helena Horská , for example, talks about the government's influence on price increases. She states that when the economy reopens, most restaurateurs, hoteliers, and service providers in general will increase their prices to offset losses from the lockdown period and meet increased deferred demand. She also adds: "This demand is being inflated by other factors. Specifically, the abolition of the super-gross wage, the increase in pensions beyond the framework of valorization, the abolition of the real estate acquisition tax, and other steps that have loosened budgetary discipline so much that even after the pandemic subsides, the state treasury is expected to be short of almost 400 billion crowns during the economic boom." However, Helena Horská does not see government policy as the main cause of inflation.

The only government influence is a short quote from Petr Kříž in the daily E15, who lists high state budget deficits or rising pensions as causes. However, such statements are exceptions. According to the rest of the article and other economists cited here, however, government policy is not the main culprit of the current inflation.

The CNB sees the cause of the current high inflation elsewhere than in "poor state management". According to it, one of the main causes is "a surge in consumer demand after the dismantling of anti-epidemic measures", which leads to a sharp increase in prices in the service sector, while at the same time the growth in prices of goods has accelerated, as Helena Horská also states . However, according to the CNB, this effect also occurs in other countries. The CNB identified another significant cause of inflation as " the high growth in industrial producer prices in the world due to disruptions in supply chains, to which is added a significant increase in the price of many raw materials and materials". At the end of its commentary, the CNB writes about "unexpectedly strong and widespread inflationary pressures from the domestic and foreign economies" . CNB Governor Rusnok has previously pointed out that the government's budgetary policy is at least partly causing today's level of inflation. On the other hand, CNB Councilor Aleš Michl stated that the government "cannot really be held responsible" for inflation.

Petr Fiala emphasizes in his statement that economists and the Czech National Bank attribute equal credit for rising inflation to international factors and the previous government's economic management. The statements of some economists may be in line with the Prime Minister's statement, although this is clearly a minority position. However, the published positions of representatives of the Czech National Bank are completely inconsistent with the Prime Minister's statement - the Czech National Bank attributes the main responsibility for rising inflation to international influences. We therefore assess Fiala's statement as untrue.

Let us add that in November (.pdf) 2021, the inflation rate in the Czech Republic was below the European Union average, at 4.8 percent. Finally, let us also state that we have verified Petr Fiala's statements about inflation in the past.
